summary: Mike Sullivan (Tom Hanks) is an enforcer for powerful Depression-era Midwestern mobster John Rooney (Paul Newman). Rooney's son, Connor (Daniel Craig), is jealous of the close bond they share, and when Mike's eldest son, Michael (Tyler Hoechlin), witnesses a hit, Connor uses the incident as an excuse to murder Sullivan's wife (Jennifer Jason Leigh) and youngest son. Forced to flee, Sullivan and Michael set out on a journey of revenge and self-discovery.

RTP is a story of fathers and sons. Paul Newman plays an Irish gang boss with a mean, killer son Daniel Craig, while Tom Hanks plays his best hitman Sullivan who has nosey son of his own. Sullivan's son sneaks along while Daddy and Craig make a fatal visit to one of their lackey's gone astray, and sonny boy sees the hit. This sets off an irreversible spiral of death and destruction that gives the already gloomy story an inevitable. biblical twist. Will Sullivan's son be spared? Will Newman allow his own horrible son to be cut loose? 

It is more than a touch gloomy and the casting, script and camera work don't provide much relief. Newman and Hanks are excellent, as is Stanley Tucci as Capone's man Frank Nitty, and Jude Law as a sick hit man hired to snuff Hanks. But that's the thing that makes it new noir - that inevitable ending you can see coming miles away. So kudos all around - half a point off for too much rain. Not an uplifting experience but a hell of a movie.

Directed by Sam Mendes who would later helm two of the rebooted James Bond films and American Pie is a gangster film but also looking at the close bond of fathers and sons 
Based on the acclaimed graphic novel of the same name by Max Allan Collins and Richard Piers Rayner 
A very young Tyler Hoechlin, Daniel Craig, Tom Hanks, Jennifer Jason Leigh, Dylan Baker, Jude Law, Stanley Tucci, and the late Paul Newman 
In the winter of 1931 a young boy Michael and his father, Mike Sullivan are close 
They live with their wife/mother and younger brother/second son 
Sullivan is an enforcer for powerful Depression-era Midwestern mobster John Rooney
Rooney's son Connor is heavily neglected and just wants to make his old man proud 
His jealousy grows and things go off the rails when Michael witnesses a murder 
This presents an opportunity for Connor to kill Mike's wife and her second child 
Now both Mike and his son are on the run set out for revenge but learning to discover what they're both made of in the process 
It's a grueling process to place our child's life above our own, every father is a hero to his son, every son holds the future for his father, the innocence of a son is surpasses only by the fathers will to save it,
This is a very dark and moody period piece 
No joy to be had for a majority of this 
Hanks is more of the active player here whereas Hoechlin kinda disappears half the time 
Yet Mendes delivers a good enough throwback to classic noir thrillers 
The title refers to the road to hell as it were, the road to physical decay 
From what I've heard it stays pretty close to the source material and it is beautifully filmed 
Maybe I just wanted more shootouts but considering when this is taking place it is more of a moody grim experience 
Hanks really delves into playing a villainous person than we're used to seeing 
The film asks can this father legitimize this situation; can his sons soul be saved from the lifestyle he's living? 
Slogging pacing aside this is an adequate entry by Sam Mendes with some fine actors

Fully displaying the talent of the cast and the director, "Road to Perdition" is a gritty but entertaining gangster film that soars in just about every aspect. The acting is great from every single actor, with Hanks and Hoechlin being the main standouts of this film, though Law, Newman, and Craig also do very well too. The action is done fairly good, and the visual appearance and cinematography of the film is absolutely stunning. The humor is done well but sparingly, never going over the top but giving you just the right amount to not make you depressed through the runtime. Story was very great and had some very good messages to be told. The characters all carried emotional weight and seemed to have their own unique personality. My main issue is that the movie is just too long, or at least it feels that way. There are a number of scenes that are so clearly filler and could easily be cut out from the end product. Still, though, I ended up really loving "Road to Perdition" and would highly recommend it.

In "Road to Perdition" Mike Sulivan (Tom Hanks) works for a gangster named John Rooney problems during the levaivan Sulivan and Rooney working on opposite sides. Old school, pre excessive CGI and wokeness story.  It probably deserves more stars for all the effort they put in to it, but mobster flicks are not my thing.  The story is fairly pedestrian - the mob killed my family so I will get revenge.  What makes this film a cut  above that is the effort and production values.  They did a phenomenal job with the period piece (although there was no real reason to set in the 30s).  Acting and the cast are all stellar.  The father son bond is understated and subtly grows over the movie with minimal talkiness - although they both got over the tragic shooting easily enough.  Jude Law was sufficiently creepy, although Hanks, who is this fast on his feet uber cold killer, suddenly runs away like a crybaby when confronted with Law, for no apparent reason.
The narrative really loses steam in the third act but it's a hearty experience nonetheless featuring some of the best night cinematography probably ever put to film.

Some enjoyable action sequences, but the plot was predictable and a bit muddled. The assassin should have been killed when he was rolling around on the floor after having shards of glass in his face, the bodyguards should have taken cover, I highly doubt the range on the tommy gun is that good, there's no way the main character wouldn't have been shot, and it was foolish of him to let his guard down when he reached the aunt's house. There were quite a few characters when it came to the criminals, and Daniel Craig's character, his father, and the assassin could have had more development. The son wasn't really believable. The acting, cinematography, visual effects, sets/props/costumes, and soundtrack were all reasonable.
This film can't decide wether it's a dark violent thriller or a family feel-good film. Still a good watch.

Lo que mas me gustó de la película fue en como manejan la crudeza. Haciendo una gran reflexión de la misma en toda la película. No engrandeciéndola, si no mostrando su cruda realidad; Una trama que muchas veces parece ajena en las película de este estilo. Y desde mi punto de vista lo que hace especial a la misma. Sin duda otra cosa que eleva la película es el desarrollo y trasfondo que le dan a cada personaje; Mostrando a casi cada personaje con una sátira o una critica a la violencia, Centrándose en criticar de una manera estupenda el como se mueven o se movían los criminales en esa época; No solo mostrando su cara "Negra" si no en como cada antagonista ya sea hasta el protagonista tienen su lado bueno; El que los mueve y el porque. Sin duda una extraordinaria película.

An engrossing if joyless affair, Road to Perdition extracts good performances from its cast in order to craft one of the better mob films of the new century. Some of the references to real-life figures seem unnecessary and a bit distracting, but Hanks's central performance holds the film together and the rough patches are certainly outweighed by the good ones. Some aspects of Hoechlin's character reeked of coming-of-age cliches, but I enjoyed the slight subversion of expectations in his character arc. Law plays a surprisingly good creep and I liked Newman in his late-career supporting role as Rooney. Daniel Craig does a good job although I expected him to have another scene or two to explore his character. Overall, this is a solid outing form Mendes and I look forward to watching American Beauty.
Gorgeously shot and edited, Road to Perdition can occasionally be a tad predictable, but is a satisfyingly crafted gangster film/coming-of-age story nonetheless.

I thought Newman was better than Reilly and Walken in that category but not as good as Harris and Cooper (the winner). Overall, a well-shot tension-filled gangster film with a satisfying ending.

The Road to Perdition has to be admired. It's a feast for the eyes, thanks to Conrad L Hall's rich cinematography. The screenplay is tight and nearly faultless. And the acting is superb. Paul Newman and Tom Hanks in the same movie? Your expectations will be fulfilled. 
The story takes place in Rock Island, Illinois in 1931. Hanks plays Michael Sullivan, a hit man for mob boss John Rooney (Newman). But Sullivan is not some noir gangster. He lives in a nice house with a loving wife (Jennifer Jason Leigh) and two young sons. Nobody in the family says much about his profession. The youngest son asks his older brother Michael what his dad does, and Michael says he goes on "missions" for Mr. Rooney. Sullivan's wife must know about his profession, but she's not saying anything. 
One night, Sullivan is sent on a job with Rooney's son Connor (Danial Craig) to strong-arm a man who has been ripping off Rooney. Connor, who is a loose cannon, ends up shooting him. Michael, curious about what his dad does for a living, hides out in the back of the car and witnesses the hit. He's terrified, and he is discovered and sworn to secrecy by his dad. But Connor is not so sure the kid or his dad can keep a secret. 
I won't synopsize anymore; suffice it to say that Sullivan ends up on the run with Michael, tailed by another hired gun (Jude Law).
This film is dead serious (pun intended). The gravitas is overwhelming. It does take a short humorous turn about two thirds in, which I found incongruous considering the tragedy that has occurred, but that's my only complaint.
I've never been a fan of mob movies. I just have no interest in gangsters. I didn't even like Miller's Crossing. But here, the father-son dynamic is what interested me: Sullivan and Michael, Rooney and Connor. 
Newman is unbelievable in this film. At age 77, he hasn't lost his commanding presence. A Rooney, he considers himself an honorable man, and the dichotomy between his self-image as a benevolent patriarch and a man who orders hits is the source of his angst. A mobster with a conscience? You decide.
Hanks has never had a more serious role that I can remember. He may seem like a strange choice to play a mobster, but he pulls it off effortlessly. He, too, seems to have a conscience, but his loyalty to Rooney seems to dominate. After all, Rooney has provided him with a good living for himself and a comfortable life for his family.
Hall won a well deserved Oscar in 2003 for his work in this film. Director Sam Mendes should have won an award for his direction. Newman won an Oscar for best supporting actor. I'm normally wary of Oscar-winning films because I tend to stay away from the Hollywood mainstream. But this one is so virtuosic and so masterfully presented, it must be recognized.
It's a movie with a solid story, good character arcs and good pacing. The acting is good and the way it's shot compliments the type of movie. Overall pretty solid movie.
Beautifully made. Deep cast. Well-acted. Great story.

7.25/10. A bit slow to start and fairly subdued throughout, Road to Perdition is an authentic period piece that grows into an intense enough crime film that features good directing, great performances, and a thoughtful story. Tom Hanks is stellar as always, while the supporting cast are wonderful. The multiple layers of family drama are engaging, even if they take quite a bit of winding exposition to set up. The 1930's Chicago setting is rich, as is the cinematography; there are a lot of gorgeous shots, even as blood and rain-soaked bodies bodies hit the pavement. It is effective as a father/son film, but I thought was more intriguing for it's revenge plot, which admittedly is made richer because of the paternal relationship. Try to watch it when you have energy - even though it is pretty good, it might also lull unsuspecting viewers into a nap if you aren't careful or fully engaged by character-first-action-second flicks.
one of the best for me watched it 3 times already

I see a lot of reviews calling this rote, thanks to its similarities to Godfather and various other Gangster flicks. But seriously, are we supposed to not attempt anything similar to what a classic film has done ever again? Or is this another case of reviewers trying to be clever... Because it's a pretty solid adaptation of the comic. It's a dour, pensive gangster picture, with great performances and gorgeous cinematography. Do people just have a hard time taking Tom Hanks as a badass? Because he totally pulls it off here...

The acting from Hanks, Newman, and Law (plus Mike Jr.) is superb and really draws the viewer in. The plot is more nuanced and interesting than one might expect - and it really explores the powerful dynamics between fathers and sons. I enthusiastically recommend this film.

I don't see what the big deal is with this movie. Don't get me wrong, it isn't terrible, but it isn't terrific either. 
On the good side, it doesn't surprise me that it won an Academy Award for best cinematography, it is indeed well, and stylishly shot. It's also got a golden cast, with Tom Hanks, Paul Newman, Jude Law and Daniel Craig. There is also a very strong theme of fatherhood in this film, at different levels, which I found very interesting. Loyalty is another strong theme. 
Unfortunately, those themes could've been much more explored, it feels a little bit superficial sometimes. It therefor for me is reduced to a very second-rate crime/drama. It also lacks thrills. If both of those elements were more explored, it would've been better. 
Overall, Road to Perdition was a alright flick which does have a few things to offer, and which can pass the time if you don't have anything to do. But I've seen much better genre pics. For the viewer to see for himself!
very good movie. Tom Hanks, Craig Daniels, & Jude Law... how do you go wrong? i loved the premise & the execution was great.
This was such a touching story. The relationship between father and son is so beautiful.
A pretty nice watch with an unpredictable ending. Didn’t know Tom Hanks could play a tough guy so well.
Paul Newman and Tom Hanks with a great plot, period drama and about as non formula as you can get. How's it get much better.
Dark, twisting and a great revenge story.
This film spoke to me on every level. The acting,sets and period effects were right on. It also delivered a potent message.One of my all-time favorites.

The mobsters in Sam Mendes' Road to Perdition appear to be their own worst enemies and surely got low to middling marks in their Gangster 101 class.  For example, when engaged in a gunfight in the middle of a dark street, take cover instead of standing under a streetlight, blasting into the dark.  Furthermore, when whacking one of your own, do not give the whackee a note intended for an outside party with the terms regarding how to kill the whackee; always keep the whacking in-house.  The characters in the film always seem to be walking through shadows with contemplative expressions glued to their faces.  When they speak, it's in hushed tones filled with dramatic pauses.  Despite all of this, the cast has some huge star power.  Jude Law is great as a photographer/killer who likes to "shoot the dead."  I wish he'd been in it more…a lot more.
Really leaves you thinking at the end with a powerful message that is up to the viewer to decide if it's about fatherhood, honor or nothing else but murderous revenge
I miss some of the violence of the comic but this is well acted powerfully told and a nice sendoff for Newman.
A well-made mob movie with satisfying performances and story.

Sam Mendes' directorial signature evolved and finalized for further growth in his second picture as his first definitive masterpiece, adapting an independent graphic novel with thematically driven brilliance of rough-edged beauty through graceful cinematography marking a finest hour, soulful emotionally channeling score, and flawlessly casted performances excelling in deepening a cinematic classic. (A)

Sam Mendes' Depression-era mob film is an admirable work of cinematography about the relationships of fathers and sons who get caught up in the nasty world of crime, but the fate of the characters is predictable from the beginning.
Excellent movie. Tom Hanks gives a great performance and you really fall in love with him as the movie progresses.

This mob drama was great. Tom Hanks, Paul Newman, Daniel Craig, Jude Law, Jennifer Jason Leigh, and the rest of the cast did a great job in this movie. The plot to the movie was very dramatic and intense. There's even a shocking discovery that character Michael Sullivan played by Tom Hanks finds as well. It'll make the movie interesting. I would recommend this movie. You probably would enjoy it.
Not my type of movie but I liked it... Tom hanks can do no wrong in my book.

Georgously shot and very well acted especially by Paul Newman. Road to Perdition is a call back to the 1930s style Mafia hit thrillers. Another masterpiece. Another amazing journey. Another awesome film. Although I do say Tom Hanks was a bit missed cast for the main role. But the story and acting were on key!
Great Movie, pace is a little slow, but still worth a watch

This is a top notch movie all around, can’t believe I didn’t see it sooner.
Well written, acted & filmed.  Recommend it!

Road To Perdition Pros: Phenomenal Acting Amazing Directing Strong Writing Stunning Cinematography Magnificent Editing Brilliant Pacing Beautiful Set and Costume Design Outstanding Storyline Great Music & Sound (Musical Score, Sound Design, etc.) Explores its themes about father love and masculinity in an emotionally affecting manner Cons: - None Overall Grade: A+ (10/10)

This movie is a complete hit! The  storyline, direction, sound effects, and the play; all ingenious. From the start to the finish, the movie keeps you hooked and the men in there have made sure that the audience watches the movie open-eyed at every turn! The only one aspect that I think could've been worked on more is the lighting. there were certain scenes where one just couldn't know what was happening. Apart from that, this movie is a must watch!
Neither Tom Hanks, Daniel Craig or Jude Law have been in a better movie. This movie is captivating from the first line of dialogue to the last.
Some might complain about the film's lukewarm ending. But I think the point of this movie was to show how a father's criminal life can affect a family.

Amazing performance from Tom Hanks, one of the finest actors of his generation. The ending was a bit twisted and sad, but that's what makes the film memorable and live up to the hype of its dark graphic comics.
A great, underrated film. Great acting performances all around, but the one to really watch out for is the breakthrough performance by Daniel Craig.

A sensitive and patient film with a wonderful aural landscape and Mendes' trademark respect for the craft of acting, particularly that of the silent type. Lingering looks at the beautiful and tangible landscape of 1930's New York is shared by lingering looks at actors acting up a storm under a mask of something else.
POV is all important; perspective literally, including those of light and dark and through glass and reflection, and figuratively, as in the ways in which your view of people change as you grow and widen your understanding of the world.
Daniel Craig is surprisingly solid and Tom Hanks is the lynchpin of the movie, a reason to revisit after all these year and acknowledge that it has aged very well. A sedate and ponderously shot and edited movie but also energetic and powerful when it needs to be. It has a sharp and careful screenplay, neither too showy or too rote or too telegraphing. A lot of that has to do with Mendes and his calculation of every cause and effect of his choices.
The ending moments are a triumph of the medium of cinema and it's a great classic-feeling exercise in mood.

Beautifully shot and paced well, Road to Perdition is one of the better prohibition era gangster flicks out there.  While I couldn't entirely buy Tom Hanks as a mob hitman, he did a great job in the role nonetheless as he always does.  Paul Newman was aces here as well.  Pre-007 Daniel Craig plays a convincing sleazebag, and Jude Law is one menacing creep here.  Certain elements like the bank robbery montage felt cliche and as a whole the plot wasn't anything groundbreaking and sometimes predictable.  Still, this is a very good film technically speaking and performance-wise with a pleasant and sometimes charming atmosphere.
A gripping drama that plays more on the relationship between father and son rather than a standard gangster film.  A must see!

Good movie, but plot is too cliche and predictable. Performance, direction, music, cinematography are top-notch. Script seems a little cliche. A lot of characters are underdeveloped. Connor, Maguire just don’t make any sense. But yeah, just for the movie and cinematography, definitely worth a watch.

A surprisingly great movie! The cinematography and general mood of the film are what make it so great and Tom Hanks elevates this to must watch status. A classic mob movie that does not get the credit it deserves. Highly recommended!

It might not seem this amazing on paper, but my god it was phenomenal. Its brings life into the mafia genre with better development and less swearing and violence. The performances were fantastic across the board, especially Tom Hanks. With a story that is both intense, entertaining, and powerfully moving. You have a must see film by Sam Mendes that well-fully provides an amazing father and son connection.

A stunning gangster film of quiet manner.

Sam Mendes directed what is likely going to be remembered as his greatest film with Road to Perdition (2002). Mendes approached his direction with a steady hand alongside his cinematographer, Conrad L. Hall, to create haunting visuals for his mobster drama.

Every scene is shot so beautifully that many of the images from Road to Perdition are burned into my brain now. The rain sequences, in particular, are so visceral to witness that they offset the brutal violence so nicely.

David Self's script is a wonderful testament to fatherhood and loyalty with many crime saga themes. Max Allen Collins' comic series is brought to life with punching lines of intense bluntness and clever dialogue of biting wit.

Thomas Newman's score is composed of lovely piano melodies and tender sweeping symphonies that sound of forlorn pains akin to those suffered by the gangsters within the film. Road to Perdition's score underscores the serene tone and bittersweet excitement of bloody gunshots throughout the film.

The cast of Road to Perdition is phenomenal all around. Tom Hanks is gripping as the hit-man gone rogue for revenge. Hanks plays a stoic father and a menacing figure dealing out a hail of bullets with ease. His quiet nuanced performance gives you everything you need in a leading man. Hanks is cool, strong, thoughtful, and patient as Michael Sullivan. Tom Hanks gives, perhaps, his peak acting in Road to Perdition.

Paul Newman is a revelation of subtle, yet intimidating acting in Road to Perdition. In what was Newman's last great role, he finds the heart of Irish mob godfather John Rooney with his gentle and likewise fearsome performance. Newman understands the character is a man who has killed his whole life to attain peace for his sons, while regretting all his bloodshed. His final words on screen are ground shaking. Paul Newman was a classic cool actor and Road to Perdition is a respectable way to go out with a bang!

Jennifer Jason Leigh is excellent as Hanks' wife Annie. She is the kindly mother that can be stern as needed. Leigh completely captures a realistic suburban mom involved with the mob. Jennifer Jason Leigh is always a top tier actress and Road to Perdition is no exception.

Jude Law is terrifying as Macguire. His sleazy assassination and corpse photographer persona is an unsettling combination. Law gives one of his best performances as you cannot forget his cruel and sudden violence.

Similarly, Daniel Craig gives one of his most memorable roles in Road to Perdition. His rapidly unnecessary violence feels so monstrous and callous. Craig plays the self-righteous creep with ease.

Lastly, Stanley Tucci and Ciaran Hinds both display fantastic quietly threatening characters in their respective supporting roles. They manage to mesmerize while they are on screen. I must mention the excellent performance from the young Tyler Hoechlin as Michael. His attachment and respect for Tom Hanks is clear as his acting is very convincing for such a young boy.

In conclusion, Sam Mendes might never have matched his early success with his erotic drama American Beauty (1999), if not for his riveting gangster thriller Road to Perdition. This film should have won Best Picture over The Pianist in all honesty.

Road To Perdition is a character driven dramatic thriller about a relationship between a father and a son which is brewed at a critical stage and higher stakes. 

Despite of portraying an essential chapter or episode of a young kid, the writing wisely accounts in the bonding of him with his father from the scratch. And it is so well fed to the audience that despite of its dark tone and poignant theme, there is a cathartic experience on each tiny moments of them. 

One of the primary strengths of the feature is its uncertainty and unexpected outcome that it evaluates keeping the audience tangled in its world where the sense of urgency too factors in a lot. 

Each supporting character gets enough range and space to factor in and work effectively which shows how the makers were chewing the characters properly and were not in any rush. 

The costumes designing is out of the park and so is the finely detailed production design but what draws in most of the attention is the metaphorical cinematography that is just pure passion throughout the course of it. An elevating background score, glorifying camera work and perfect editing are too some of its rich details. 

The writing is simple as it can be but sensible and justifying as you've never seen. Mendes; the director, at the heart of it, has done a tremendous work on executing such a balanced feature. 

Hanks has never been more impactful with a excellent support from Newman, Craig and Law. Jaw dropping visuals, whistle-blowing dialogues and a heartbreaking chemistry are the high points of the feature that makes you look twice. 

Road To Perdition is more salvation than damnation since it has such a risky tone to explore at let along triumph over it; a masterstroke by the makers.

Road to Perdition is the immaculately directed, violent gangster piece from Sam Mendes, who adapted the story from the graphic novel series of the same name, and boy does it leave an impression! The film stars Tom Hanks, playing against-type, as a mob enforcer who is forced to go on the run when a tragedy befalls his family after his son witnesses something he wasn't supposed to see. Him and his son then work as a team robbing the crime boss's bank accounts until they can come to an understanding, all the while being pursued by a ruthless assassin played brilliantly by Jude Law. The acting in this film is extraordinary with nearly every main cast member playing out of their comfort zone with Hanks being a skilled killer, Paul Newman playing the conflicted mob boss, Daniel Craig playing the skiddish and jealous heir to the crime family, and of course Jude Law as the psychopathic hitman who revels in taking photos of the dead. This is a truly arresting piece of filmmaking and with Oscar-winning cinematography, the images jump from the pages of the graphic novel to the screen in great detail and many of the shots will stick in my mind permanently! It's a great story, with well-rounded and memorable characters, features flawless direction from Sam Mendes, and the gorgeous cinematography is truly an impressive feat!

Every year, there are always a few select films snubbed from contention in the race for Oscar's best picture. Every decade, there are one or two films that stand out amongst those as the best of the unjustly left behind. One such picture is Director Edward Zwick's Glory, and another is Sam Mendes' Road to Perdition. Though not completely overlooked during awards season -- Conrad Hall won a much-deserved posthumous Oscar for his exemplary cinematography and the film received several additional nominations -- the absence of a Best Picture nomination, as with Glory, seems one of the great injustices in the long history of the awards. Nevertheless, those missing notches from its belt in no way detract from what a remarkable piece of filmmaking this is. Road to Perdition is easily one of the most beautiful pictures ever made. It's got a great cast and an even better story as complimentary pieces, but there's no doubt that it's in Mendes' and Hall's brilliant craftsmanship where Road to Perdition will find its legacy as one of cinema's finest works of art.
